ygData.subject: RE: [cantera] MSVC 7.0 project files: installation problems.
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi, Sorry for the installation errors, and thanks for working through a few of them. The MS VC v7.0 port is still pretty much a work in progress. 1)  cvode -

Hi,
  Sorry for the installation errors, and thanks for working through
a few of them. The MS VC v7.0 port is still pretty much a work in progress.

1)  cvode -> there was an absolute path name in the project file.
           I replaced it with a relative path name.

2) I forgot to include in my directions a rather troubling point about
   compatibility issues between python modules and MS VC++. I've added a
step
   to the README file that describes how to compile cantera with
   MS VC++ v7.0. (win32/README):

   An error exit is generated by python v. 2.3's distutils module
   whenever a user module is compiled with MS VC++ v7.0. Note, python was
   compiled with  MS VC++ v6.0. I have found that just disabling the error
   exit leads to acceptable behavior with no problems.

   To disable the error exit, edit the file:
          /cygdrive/c/python23/Lib/distutils/msvccompiler.py
   Comment out lines 211 to 215 with "#" symbols.

   Note, this module generates compiler command lines for python. During
   Cantera's python build process, the distutils module actually takes over
   the build process from Cantera's makefile, and carries out the
build/install
   operations. Therefore, there is no way around this step.

   Note, python 2.4 is in alpha testing as of 9/2004. It's being built with
   MSVC++ v7.0. I'm not sure if this means similar problems await for
Cantera users
   who want to use python 2.4 with MSVC++ v6.0.

   (HKM -> I'll try to find out more information about this whole issue in
    the near future i.e., is there an upgraded distutils module?)

So, taking out an error exit from distutils module seems to work. The python
test problems all work. It's certainly less of a can-o-worms than
recompiling
python. However, I do admit to being a little jittery with
binary-compatibility
issues.

3) Python is needed to convert the cti format into the ctml format (which is
   xml based). The c++ kernel reads the ctml format using native c++.
   However, most of the cxx_examples use cti input files. Therefore, python
   is needed to run these examples. I think you're bringing up an
interesting
   point about whether the c++ kernel should require python to function and
whether
   the cti to ctml format conversion operation should be considered a kernel
   operation. If so, then the cti to ctml converter should be written in
c++,
   which actually is no small amount of work; it's much easier to write
parsers 
   in python.

4) clib.dll is placed in Cantera's python site-package directory:
      ~/python23/lib/site-package/Cantera
   clib.dll is needed for Cantera's python interface.
   I've also changed the makefile script to place it in Cantera's install
lib
   directory.

5) cxx_examples and the programs in test_programs aren't currently copied to
the
   install directory tree from the build directory tree.

Best wishes,
Harry



-----Original Message-----
From: brooksmoses1 [mailto:brooksmail@...]
Sent: Wednesday, September 15, 2004 10:46 PM
To: cantera@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [cantera] MSVC 7.0 project files: installation problems.


(Apologies if this shows up twice -- I tried to send it once before, 
but it appears to have not gone through.)

At 07:45 PM 8/27/2004, David Goodwin wrote:
> Thanks to Harry Moffat, there is now a complete set of project files to 
> compile Cantera using Visual C++ .NET on a PC.  No Fortran compiler is 
> required.  They are currently available only via anonymous CVS.  To get 
> them, you first need to check out the Cantera source distribution using 
> anonymous CVS, and then go into the top-level Cantera directory and 
> delete the entire 'win32' directory.  Then from this top-level 
> directory type at a command prompt 'cvs co win32' to check out the new 
> win32 module, which will replace the old win32 directory.  See the 
> README file in this directory for complete instructions on how to build 
> Cantera with Visual C++ .NET.

I just tried to compile with this, following the directions in the 
relevant README file, and had a few problems.

First, when trying to build cantera.sln, I was unable to build 
"cvode" because it couldn't find the header files.  Copying the 
header files into the directory with the cvode source files seems to 
work as a workaround, but I presume there's some path munged up that 
can be easily fixed.

More significantly, I can't get the makefiles to work right; they 
keep exiting with errors.  Specifically, on the "make win" command:

==============================================================
BROOKS-GCEP:~/Projects/Cantera_Source/cantera> make win
/usr/bin/install -c -d build/include/cantera
rm -r -f build/include/cantera/*
/usr/bin/install -c -d build/include/cantera/kernel
/usr/bin/install -c -d build/include/cantera/kernel/oneD
/usr/bin/install -c -d build/include/cantera/kernel/zeroD
/usr/bin/install -c -d build/include/cantera/kernel/converters
/usr/bin/install -c -d build/include/cantera/kernel/transport
/usr/bin/install -c Cantera/cxx/include/*.h build/include/cantera
/usr/bin/install -c config.h build/include/cantera
/usr/bin/install -c Cantera/src/*.h build/include/cantera/kernel
/usr/bin/install -c Cantera/src/oneD/*.h 
build/include/cantera/kernel/oneD
/usr/bin/install -c Cantera/src/zeroD/*.h 
build/include/cantera/kernel/zeroD
/usr/bin/install -c Cantera/src/converters/*.h 
build/include/cantera/kernel/converters
/usr/bin/install -c Cantera/src/transport/*.h 
build/include/cantera/kernel/transport
cd Cantera/python; make win
make[1]: Entering directory 
`/brooks/Projects/Cantera_Source/cantera/Cantera/python'
touch src/pycantera.cpp
(c:/python23/python.exe setup.py build)
running build
running build_py
running build_ext
error: Python was built with version 6 of Visual Studio, and 
extensions need to be built with the same version of the compiler, 
but it isn't installed.
make[1]: *** [_winbuild] Error 1
make[1]: Leaving directory 
`/brooks/Projects/Cantera_Source/cantera/Cantera/python'
make: *** [python] Error 2
==============================================================


If I take out the makefile command relating to the python stuff, then 
all the rest seems to run, but when I eventually get done with the 
"make win-install" command (which I also had to take a python-stuff 
command out of), and try to run the cxx-examples.exe file, I get all 
sorts of errors about "ctml-write module not found".

Is there a way to resolve this, or do I need to get the Python source 
and recompile it myself?  (And is doing this the family-sized can of 
worms that I fear it will be?)

And, while I'm asking: does this mean that those examples are 
depending on Python to run, despite being part of the cxx example 
set?  Does this imply that all C++ cantera programs will need Python?

Also, some smaller questions related to the installation: the 
"cantera" solution builds a clib.dll file, but it doesn't actually 
seem to get put anywhere by the installation process.  What is 
supposed to happen with that?  And the cxx-examples.exe and similar 
example stuff; is that supposed to get put somewhere in the installed 
directory?


(And, as a final note: it might be useful to somewhere note that the 
Matlab compiler is needed to compile the Matlab interface.  Although 
perhaps that's obvious to people who, unlike me, know the first thing 
about making Matlab interfaces!)

Thanks,
- Brooks
